The chlorine shut-off solenoid valve must be opened manually but is shut-off during a 
GA System alarm.  A manual shut-off override valve is located on the rail platform to 
avoid an inadvertent valve opening.  The chlorine line contains a check valve on the 
platform side of the rail car flex hose to prevent backflow in the chlorine system.

      Liquid chlorine will be flowed at 1.5 tons/hour from the chlorine rail car into an 
agitated, 6,500 gal polyethylene bleach reaction tank to produce sodium hypochlorite 
(NaOCl) bleach and NaCl salt.  Chlorine addition to the bleach reaction tank will be 
controlled with an automatic shut-off valve and a manual control valve. GA System 
sensors set to alarm at 6 ppm are located at the southeast and northwest corners of the 
bleach reaction and settling tanks. 

      Concurrent with chlorine addition, 50% sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and dilute 
NaOH will be added to the bleach reaction tank.  Chlorine addition will be monitored 
with an oxidation-reduction potential (ORP) monitor in the bleach reaction tank and a 
second ORP monitor in recirculation cooling loop for the bleach reaction tank.  If the 
residual chlorine in the bleach reaction tank drops, a local horn will be sounded and the 
chlorine automatic shut-off valve feeding the bleach reaction tank will be shut.   A 100 
deg F maximum temperature is maintained in the bleach reaction tank by pumping the 
solution through a water cooled plate heat exchanger in the recirculation loop.  The 
bleach will be decanted from the bleach reaction tank and gravity flow through two 6,500 
gal polyethylene settling tanks prior to being pumped to the chloropicrin manufacturing 
process.

      Emergency back-up power is provided to all ventilation fans and alarm systems 
via a diesel-powered generator and transfer switch (generator set).  If power to the facility 
is interrupted, the generator set will start and provide power to all ventilation fans and 
emergency sys

tems simultaneously in approximately eight seconds.  The generator set 
will remain on for twenty minutes once utility power is restored to avoid power 
fluctuations.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

      Niklor facility is in compliance with Federal and State Process Safety 
Management requirements.  Niklor accidental release prevention program is based on the 
following key elements:

*  Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
*  Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, 
emergency responders, and contractors.
*  Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
*  Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation 
and maintenance staff participation and review.
*  Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
*  Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of 
the operators.
*  High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
*  Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using 
qualified staff.

      Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained 
breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators in case of a chlorine release, 
awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, and the presence of chlorine 
detectors and alarms with remote monitoring.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

      Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting 
and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as 
detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background 
information and MSDS sheets.

      Equipment safety information was compiled on chlorine storage and handling.  
Specifications for the chlorine storage and handling are collected and provided in one 
place for easy re

ith offsite response officials 
and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The emergency response plan has been 
coordinated with local response agencies (Kern County Environmental Health Services). 

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

      Niklor facility is an agricultural chemical manufacturing and chemical transfer 
facility.  Anhydrous chlorine (chlorine) will be received at the facility in 90-ton rail tank 
cars.  Chlorine rail cars will be unloaded one at a time with operator access to the dome 
from a raised platform.  Solid state sensors comprising the Gas Alarm (GA) System, 
calibrated to alarm at 6 ppm chlorine, are located on the east and west sides of the 
chlorine rail car.  When unloading operations are underway, the west sensor will be 
placed in the rail car dome.  An alarm condition in any GA System sensor will close all 
rail car supply line valves, sound a plant-wide alarm and dial-out. A manual pull station 
is also present on the rail platform which will manually activate the GA System alarms. A 
closed-circuit video (CCV) camera is placed to record rail car unloading activities.  All 
CCV cameras are monitored at the main office.  A spill collection pan is provided for all 
rail tank cars and is connected to a 20,000 gallon capacity sump.

      The chlorine rail car will be pressurized with nitrogen to 100 psi during 
unloading.  The chlorine line connecting the rail car with the bleach preparation area is 1-
inch diameter schedule 160 welded carbon steel pipe and is protected with a rupture disc 
(300 psi) and expansion chamber.  The expansion chamber is fitted with a pressure 
switch and indicator with audible and visible alarm located in the bleach preparation area.   
The chlorine line contains an automatic shut-off valve located on the rail car side of the 
rail car flex hose.  The automatic shut-off valve requires nitrogen to open and is

Niklor Chemical Company (Niklor) is building an agricultural chemical
manufacturing plant and chemical transfer facility near the unincorporated town of 
Mojave, in Kern County, California.  Niklor is proposing to store and handle chlorine at 
this facility.  Niklor facility will use chlorine as part of its product manufacturing process.  
It will basically use chlorine to make bleach, which will be used to make chloropicrin.  
Niklor facility chlorine storage and handling process will be subject to the U.S. 
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and also to the 
California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations.  These 
regulations require the submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  An integral part 
of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the 
facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.
      
	The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive 
Summary: 
*  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
*  General facility and regulated substances information.
*  Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific 
prevention steps.
*  Five-year accident history summary.
*  Emergency response program summary.
*  Planned changes to improve safety.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

      Niklor Chemical Company accidental release prevention policy involves the use 
of proven technology, training the staff in operation and maintenance practices, and use 
of tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the 
State of California and EPA's Prevention Program will be adhered to, including key 
elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.

      Niklor has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for chlorine storage and 
handling to facilitate coordination and emergency planning w

terials, and processing conditions.  Training, PSI, operating procedures, and 
maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.

Internal Compliance Audits

      	The Niklor Chemical Company will certify every three years (or earlier) that 
compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements are met and that 
procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.

      The compliance audit will consist of separating the CalARP RMP program 
elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and 
effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team will complete a Compliance Audit 
Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist.  The Compliance Audit 
Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, 
and certification by the audit leader and the facility Manager.  The Compliance Audit 
Checklist details the requirements of each CalARP RMP element and contains questions 
that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of 
the following three sections:

*  Records Review: A review of the CalARP RMP written Prevention Program.
*  On-Site Conditions: The audit team will review the program elements based on 
observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
*  Interviews:  The program elements will be evaluated by interviewing personnel 
from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and 
contractors.

      Team members will record CalARP RMP program deficiencies identified during 
the audit on the checklist.

Incident Investigation

      The Niklor Chemical Company incident investigation procedures describe 
incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant 
personnel.  The incident investigation shall be started promptly but no later than 48 hours 
after the event. The Niklor Chemical Company will promptly address and resolve all 
recommendations

and shall implement the recommendations in a timely manner to 
prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports will be retained on 
Niklor Chemical Company file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports 
are completed.  The report will include all the information required by CalARP RMP 
rule.

Five-year Accident History Summary

      The Niklor facility chlorine system will be a new process.  Thus, no accidents 
have occurred involving chlorine at the Niklor Chemical Company during the last five-
years.

Emergency Response Program Summary

      The Niklor Chemical Company is a first responder, its trained employees will 
respond to chlorine accidental releases.  Depending on the severity of the accidental 
release, external resources such as the Kern County Environmental Health Services may 
be solicited to aid in handling a chlorine release.

      As part of the emergency response program, the Niklor Chemical Company has 
developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting 
public health and the environment. The following elements are included:

(a)	An emergency response plan, maintained at the Chemical Manufacturing Plant 
and Transfer Facility:

*  Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various 
Niklor Chemical Company personnel.
*  Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response 
organizations.
*  Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorine 
process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of Niklor Chemical 
Company personnel who will respond to chlorine releases.
*  Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the Niklor Chemical Company.
*  Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies 
about accidental releases.
*  Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment 
necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information 
on

emergency health care.
*  Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.

(b)	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, 
testing, and maintenance. 

(c)	Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorine 
storage and handling process.

(d)	Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to 
reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

      25 changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in July 23, 
2004, when the process hazard analysis was performed for the chlorine storage and 
handling facility.  All of these 25 recommendations have been implemented, except one 
recommendation which requires detailed study of the feasibility of using Midland 
actuators on the chlorine rail cars.  It is expected that evaluation of this recommendation 
will be completed by December 31, 2004.

are on file at the facility. 

Process Hazard Analysis 

      A detailed process hazard analysis (PHA) was conducted for the chlorine storage 
and handling system on July 26, 2004.  The PHA will be updated again within a five-year 
period or whenever there is a major change in the process.  Based on the PHA, a list of 
recommended actions was developed to further improve the chlorine safety and all the 
critical recommendations have been implemented.

      A seismic walkthrough was recently completed based on the 2004 LEPC Region 
1 guidance document.  Based on this walkthrough, four recommendations were made and 
all of these recommendations have been implemented.

Operating Procedures

      Niklor has prepared written operating procedures for chlorine storage and 
handling that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to 
chlorine. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information.   Written operating 
procedures include delivery and storage of chlorine, problems, and remedies.

Training

      	Niklor Chemical Company ensures that each employee involved with the chlorine 
storage and handling process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is 
trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures.  The Niklor Chemical 
Company employee training documentation files include training records for each 
employee assigned to chlorine storage and handling process.  The training ensures that 
the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the 
duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the 
operating procedures.  Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:

*  Safety Information.
*  Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
*  Ma

intenance Procedures.
*  Procedures for the delivery, storage, and handling of chlorine.
*  CalARP RMP Program contents.
*  Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.
    
  	Refresher training will be provided at least every three years to each employee 
operating the chlorine process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the 
current operating procedures.  In addition, Niklor Chemical Company will ensure that 
operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after 
major modifications.

Contractors

      Niklor Contractor procedures specify the information required to be provided to 
the contractors performing work on or near the chlorine system, the training requirements 
for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they 
have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  Niklor is required to 
provide information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes, obtain, and 
evaluate information regarding the contractor's safety program. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

      Niklor has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is 
conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the 
chlorine system that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation.  
The required conditions prior to startup include:

*  Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.
*  Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.
*  A PHA has been performed for any new facilities and recommendations have been 
resolved or implemented prior to startup.
*  At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.
*  Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.

      These procedures ensure that no new/significantly modified process will start-up 
and no regulated substances wi

ll be introduced into such a process prior to the pre-startup 
safety review.  This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to 
go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately 
addressed.  This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process 
is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 

      Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance 
procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance 
personnel.

      Niklor operates a program that generates a task order for performance of the 
preventive maintenance routine after a designated time past the closing of the previous 
task order for that maintenance.  Description of the work to be performed is included with 
the printed work order.  In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the 
General Operation and Maintenance Manual. 

      Niklor Chemical Company will document inspection, testing, and maintenance of 
chlorine related equipment and assure the performance is done in accordance with the 
recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

      Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or 
similar flame or spark producing operations.  The procedures call for the issuance of a hot 
work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorine railcars and other areas 
deemed appropriate as described in the procedures.  Fire prevention and protection 
systems are in place prior to the issuance of the hot work permit.  The permit indicates 
the dates the work is authorized for, the location and specific operational requirements 
and is kept on file in the administrative office.
